18.81.text:
I'm Lloyd Minor, Dean of the
Stanford School of Medicine.

21.22.text:
It's a great pleasure to welcome
all of you in the room today,

24.32.text:
and those of you who are
watching through the web

27.76.text:
We're in for a very
exciting day and a half,

30.39.text:
and I want to begin
today's session

32.33.text:
by thanking the many people
who've made today happen.

36.21.text:
First, a big shout out and
round of applause and thanks

39.72.text:
to Dr. Dennis Wall
who's passion and vision

43.04.text:
has led to Childx
being a reality.

45.17.text: Let's have a round of applause.

50.58.text:
And then to Robin Daines and the
magnificent staff at the Dean's

53.50.text:
Office in Stanford
Medicine who have worked

55.90.text:
to make all of
the logistics work

58.86.text:
and make this great
event possible.

61.32.text:
I'm really excited about what
we are starting in Childx.

66.21.text:
I'm very, very excited about
the future of pediatrics,

72.92.text:
In so many ways, our lives
are set in our childhood.

77.61.text:
The more we learn about
genetics, epigenetics,

80.57.text:
about social and behavioral
factors of health,

83.96.text:
the more we discover that
it all begins in childhood.

88.29.text:
In fact, the more we learn
about genetics the more

90.45.text:
we learn that it actually
begins at conception.

94.20.text:
And I'm really pleased that
we here at Stanford Medicine

97.77.text:
and Lucile Packard Children's
Hospital and Stanford

100.26.text:
Children's Health, both integral
parts of Stanford Medicine,

104.17.text:
are leaders in that
continuum of child health.

109.70.text:
And you're going to learn more
about the exciting advances

112.25.text:
here, and the exciting
things going on

117.35.text:
related to child
health and development

122.10.text:
Our vision at
Stanford Medicine is

124.22.text:
to lead the biomedical
revolution in precision health.

128.72.text:
Precision health is
the next generation

133.95.text:
Absolutely, we excel
here and we want

136.20.text:
to continue to excel
in the diagnosis

139.59.text:
and treatment of acute
diseases by bringing

142.49.text:
the very best science to the
benefit of every patient.

146.87.text:
And we want to take
it to the next level.

149.40.text:
We want to also develop
the science and the fields

153.30.text:
of predictive, preventative, and
preemptive medicine and health

159.49.text:
so that we can intervene before
a disease develops or at such

163.67.text:
an early stage that the
disease doesn't lead

168.89.text:
And what better place to do that
then right here at Stanford?

173.44.text:
We have the benefit
at Stanford Medicine

175.55.text:
of being an academic medical
center that is so well rooted

179.37.text:
in and encompasses and
works with and within

184.42.text:
this great research university,
Stanford University.

187.88.text:
Just across the street, we
have a magnificent school

193.41.text:
going on between our faculty,
between members of our hospital

198.15.text:
leadership, and the
faculty of engineering,

200.47.text:
and so many other schools and
departments in the university.

210.36.text:
and to create opportunities for
better health and well being

214.79.text:
for people in our communities,
people in our nation,

218.60.text:
and ultimately,
people in the world.

223.28.text:
We look forward to this
next day and a half.

225.94.text:
For those of you who
are new to Stanford,

227.65.text:
please don't hesitate
to contact us,

229.80.text:
ask us if we can
help you in any way.

232.66.text:
It's now my great pleasure to
introduce Chris Dawes, who's

236.55.text:
the President and CEO of Lucile
Packard Children's Hospital.

240.77.text:
Chris's vision and passion
have brought Lucile Packard

249.02.text:
from a very good regional
pediatrics hospital and program

254.13.text:
to now an internationally
renowned leader in child health

259.08.text:
development, medicine, surgery,
all the other components

263.65.text:
of outstanding children's
health and hospital programs.

267.48.text:
It's a great privilege
and pleasure for me

269.39.text:
to work with Chris
on a daily basis,

272.73.text:
and together, Chris, Amir
Rubin, President and CEO

276.14.text:
of Stanford Health
Care, and I are

278.71.text:
shaping the future of Stanford
Medicine in collaboration

283.27.text:
Thank you very much
for being here.

291.70.text:
I really appreciate the
wonderful introduction.

293.92.text:
And it's great to see
all of you here today.

296.64.text:
One of the things that we
talk about, well, actually,

299.23.text:
first of all, I
also want to thank

301.24.text:
Dennis Wall and the entire
team for putting this together.

304.99.text:
This is really a
magnificent conference,

307.10.text:
and we're delighted to have the
opportunity to partner not only

310.65.text:
with the School of Medicine,
but the entire university,

313.36.text:
and with that, partners
in Silicon Valley

315.40.text: to bring this to you today.

318.54.text:
One of the most exciting
areas that certainly excites

322.68.text:
me anyway is that-- and this
goes back many years-- when

327.16.text:
we started to really think
about Lucile Packard Children's

330.87.text:
Hospital and the impact it
could have on child health,

334.54.text:
what we recognized was two
very fundamental principles.

339.28.text:
And that was that of
preeminence and sustainability.

343.78.text:
And what we meant by
preeminence was that we're

347.71.text:
We received enormous
support from this community

351.04.text:
to propel the organization,
not only the hospital itself,

355.57.text:
but all of pediatrics
and obstetrics

357.74.text:
into national preeminence,
that we really

361.19.text:
had a great opportunity
to actually achieve

367.06.text: say, we shoot for the best.

368.24.text: We want to be the best.

370.58.text:
But I think we're one of the few
organizations that actually has

373.25.text:
an opportunity to
really achieve that,

375.42.text:
and that's because we're part
of this incredible Stanford

377.86.text:
community here on campus
and throughout the valley.

384.20.text:
and sustainability, in part,
has to do with economics,

387.72.text:
but the other part
of sustainability

389.68.text:
is really how do we
drive to the future.

392.47.text:
It's not about tomorrow,
it's not about next year,

394.69.text:
or even 20 years from
now, it's how are we

396.87.text:
going to have an impact
on the long term?

400.07.text:
How are we going to
really impact child health

403.73.text:
throughout the country,
throughout the world,

406.47.text: and how can we do that?

408.19.text:
And what this conference
is all about, in my view,

411.78.text:
is the work that is being
done and the work that

414.32.text:
needs to be done in
order to have a really

416.58.text:
profound impact on child
health, not only locally,

423.72.text:
And that's why it's
really an honor

425.22.text:
to be part of this organization,
and to be here today

428.40.text:
as part of this
conference where there's

430.37.text:
going to be an opportunity to
talk about the innovations that

432.91.text: are going to move us forward.

434.79.text:
And with that, the last
comment I'd like to make

437.31.text:
is that not only do we have
this chance for innovation

442.39.text:
and moving forward, but the
other great opportunity we have

447.26.text:
Because one of the greatest
advantages of conferences

450.25.text:
such as this is it brings people
together around a common series

456.89.text:
And that's what I think we can
actually achieve as well today.

459.90.text:
So I do, again, want to thank
Dennis and his entire crew.

463.44.text:
I want to thank the Child
Health Research Institute led

467.26.text:
by Dr. Hugh O'Brodovich
for providing

470.32.text: a lot of the funding for today.

472.63.text:
And again, I want to thank
Dean Minor and his entire team

480.70.text:
So again, thank
you all very much.

483.05.text:
I appreciate you
very much being here.
